4305.67.text: And they produced a beautiful digital, what they call

4308.23.text: 'Turning the Pages' where you can actually go and look at

4310.40.text: each page. It's beautiful, but it's not the same as

4313.47.text: the real thing. When we borrowed it the last time,

4317.63.text: I watched people weeping in front of this. I don't

4320.07.text: think I've ever seen anybody weep in front of an iPad,

4322.50.text: well except when it's broken or something,

4326.13.text: or when I can't get it to work. But seriously,

4329.67.text: that is the power of real things with real associations.

4333.73.text: I wanted to finish just with two things that don't even belong

4336.17.text: to us, but they're projects that we've been involved

4338.33.text: with over the last year. For the 70th anniversary of the sinking

4344.30.text: of HMAS Sydney there was some work done with families,

4354.33.text: who came back to Geraldton, and they created

4357.53.text: little story boards, and this was one a woman

4365.40.text: created and did some writing around it, for

4369.73.text: Lieutenant Eric Mayo who went down with the Sydney

4373.93.text: and she actually brought this. I get a

4378.37.text: bit emotional with this actually, which just shows

4382.47.text: you the power of collections. This was a letter

4385.23.text: that sent by Mayo's wife - this woman's

4389.33.text: grandmother - to Lieutenant Mayo. It never got to

4392.83.text: him because the Sydney went down. So it was

4394.63.text: returned to sender. It's never been opened,

4399.77.text: probably never will be opened. The granddaughter

4402.63.text: thinks it's the letter - follow me with this one -

4406.40.text: that her mother sent, sorry, her grandmother sent

4410.40.text: to her husband to say that she was pregnant with

4412.97.text: this woman's father, because it would - and the

4417.13.text: kind of poignancy of something like that, it's

4420.60.text: almost impossible to countenance and to me, I just

4424.27.text: think anybody who says that real things don't matter,

4428.10.text: real things do matter, and they do have an

4430.57.text: emotional attachment. The final one, which again

4432.43.text: will be familiar to many of you. This chap here,

4438.43.text: Keith Hayes, is something like 93 now. He's still

4441.80.text: knocking around WA and he looks a bit of a cheeky

4446.30.text: chap here. He's in the 2/2nd Commandos, from WA,

4453.00.text: and these were the guys in East Timor in the

4454.83.text: Second World War and they were the ones who held off -

4458.73.text: I mean a couple of hundred of them held off

4461.00.text: thousands of Japanese forces for months on end,

4466.30.text: and Keith was one of those, and we did an

4469.03.text: exhibition about it. Keith lent us something that again,

4474.77.text: I don't think he's ever let out of his

4476.03.text: possession since he had it. And the exhibition was

4482.07.text: what you might - it was called 'Debt of Honour'

4484.13.text: because of the debt that Peter Cosgrove actually

4488.53.text: said that the Australians owed to the Timorese,

4492.37.text: and it had all the usual things. It had military in it,

4494.63.text: it had uniforms, it had guns, but it had

4497.50.text: this pink handkerchief, and it was to me, the most poignant

4502.07.text: object in the exhibition. It's on loan to us.

4505.50.text: It doesn't belong to us. Keith lent it to us,

4507.60.text: his most precious possession. Keith was on a

4509.93.text: ration truck that went down into the Timor. It was

4514.00.text: ambushed by the Japanese and taken over. He and

4518.40.text: three of his colleagues, including three in

4520.80.text: that photograph, were thrown off the truck and told to

4522.77.text: walk behind, and then some Dutch soldiers fired on it,

4525.87.text: and as a reprisal, the Japanese shot,

4528.23.text: and bayonetted the four Australian soldiers,

4531.97.text: and left them for dead. Three of them were dead. Keith wasn't.

4538.23.text: He somehow crawled into the undergrowth

4542.13.text: and was taken in by this woman - Bertha Martinez

4546.27.text: and she, using all her local knowledge, staunched

4550.83.text: his wounds, stopped them getting infected. Somehow

4554.33.text: after a few days of nursing him, got him back to

4557.77.text: his regiment. He lived to tell the tale. He's

4562.07.text: still alive today. She gave him that handkerchief.

4568.93.text: And the reason I get emotional about this,

4570.77.text: is because I saw Keith on the night of this, and it

4572.63.text: was the first time I think he'd really talked

4574.10.text: about this, and understandably, he was quite upset,

4579.43.text: quite emotional. But what a powerful object.

4584.90.text: What a story that lies behind a very prosaic and simple

4588.67.text: looking object, and to me, that's kind of what we're all

4592.37.text: about. We're about saving the world, we're about

4596.77.text: understanding the universe and we're about trying to

4600.47.text: understand history. But above all, we're about these

4604.50.text: emotional ties that make us human, actually,

4608.80.text: and I think very late, that's where I'd like to finish.
